front.title: A Link Relation Type for Link Sets

abstract.t: This specification defines the "linkset" relation type that can be used to link to a set of links.

note.title: Note to Readers
note.t: Please discuss this draft on the ART mailing list ().
Online access to all versions and files is available on GitHub ().

section.title: Introduction
section.t: RFC 5988 specifies the HTTP "Link" header as a means to convey typed links in HTTP responses. The links are provided as the payload of the "Link" header using a syntax specified by the RFC. Cases exist in which providing links by value is impractical or impossible. In these cases, an approach to provide links by reference is desired. This specification defines the "linkset" relation type that allows doing so.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119 .

section.title: Large Number of Links
section.t: Cases exist in which a significant number of links needs to be conveyed, and, as a result, the payload of the HTTP "Link" header becomes large. It is possible to statically configure a web server to correctly handle large HTTP response headers by specifying an upper boundary for their size. But, when the number of links and the amount of bytes required for each is unpredictable estimating a reliable upper boundary is challenging. This is, for example, the case when links are determined dynamically dependent on a range of contextual factors. While HTTP [RFC 2616] defines error codes related to excess communication by the user agent ("413 Request Entity Too Large" and "414 Request-URI Too Long"), no error codes are defined to indicate that a response header exceeds the upper boundary that can be handled by the server. Applications take counter measures aimed at controlling the size of the HTTP "Link" header, for example, by limiting the links they provide to those with select relation types, thereby limiting the value of the HTTP "Link" header to clients. Providing links by reference, instead of by value, overcomes challenges related to the unpredictable nature of the extent of HTTP "Link" headers.

section.title: Third-Party Links
section.t: Cases exist in which a server other than the responding server is better placed to provide links. That other server - the linking server - may be managed by the same custodian as the responding server or by a third party trusted by the custodian of the responding server. In both cases, the linking server exposes links pertaining to web resources made available by the responding server. In order for the responding server to provide up-to-date links in the HTTP "Link" header, it needs to obtain them from the link server prior to responding to a client. Doing so increases latency, which may be unnecessary if a client is not intent on consuming links. Providing links by reference, instead of by value, removes this additional latency by avoiding server-to-server communication required to obtain links.

section.title: Link Relation for Identifying Link Sets
section.t: The "linkset" relation type can be used to refer to a resource that provides a set of links. Typically the Context IRI of these links is the URI of the responding resource but other Context IRIs MAY be used.

More than one link with a "linkset" relation type MAY be provided. Multiple such links can refer to the same set of links expressed using different serializations or to different sets of links. The use of a link with the "linkset" relation type does not preclude the provision of links with other relation types.

The entity-body of a response from the Target IRI of a link with the "linkset" relation type MAY be serialized in various ways, but the link-value format serialization described here MUST be supported. In this serialization, the entity-body MUST be formatted in the same way as the value of an HTTP "Link" header, and hence MUST comply to the "link-value" construction rule of Section 5 of RFC 5988 , and the media type of the entity-body MUST be "application/link-format" as introduced in RFC 6690 . The Context IRI of links contained in the entity-body MUST be interpreted as follows:

list.t: The Context IRI is the URI in the anchor parameter, when provided.
The Context IRI is the URI of the resource that conveys the link with the "linkset" relation type, when the anchor parameter is not provided.

section.t: For self-containdeness, the use of anchors for all links is RECOMMENDED.

section.title: Example
section.t: shows a user agent issuing an HTTP head request against resource http://example.org/resource1.

figure.title: User Agent Issues HTTP HEAD on Resource
figure.artwork: HEAD /resource1 HTTP/1.1 Host: example.org Connection: close

section.t: shows the response to the HEAD request of . The response contains a "Link" header with a link that uses the "linkset" relation type. It indicates that links are provided by a linking server at resource http://example.com/links/http://example.org/resource.

figure.title: Response to HTTP HEAD on Resource
figure.artwork: HTTP/1.1 200 OK Date: Mon, 28 Nov 2016 14:37:51 GMT Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1 Link: <http://example.com/links/http://example.org/resource1> ; rel="linkset" ; type="application/link-format" Content-Length: 5214 Content-Type: text/html;charset=utf-8 Connection: close

section.t: shows the user agent issuing an HTTP GET request against the Target IRI of the link with the "linkset" relation type shown in .

figure.title: User Agent Issues HTTP GET on Linking Server Resource
figure.artwork: GET /links/http://example.org/resource1 HTTP/1.1 Host: example.com Accept: application/link-format Connection: close
